name: Emily is Away
description: Emily is Away is an interactive story. Create a screenname and choose your path through the branching narrative.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Service Pack 2+ Processor: Intel Pentium 4 or later Memory: 512 MB RAM

reviews.review_text: This game made my mum think i actually had friends.
emily was my first internet girlfriend   she broke my heart

This game actually ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off. No matter what way you try to put it, Emily is actually emotionally abusive. Like seriously, she guilt trips and gaslights you, both of which are forms of emotional abuse. Yet the game tries to guide you towards appeasing her and acts like she's the one in the right. I ♥♥♥♥ing hate that. It makes me feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for doing absolutely nothing wrong. Go to the party at the beginning of the game? You get cucked by Brad. Don't go, and tell her to not talk to Brad? You get cucked by Travis anyway. Both of whom are jerks to her. You try to get into a relationship and try to be as nice as you can? She acts like you're a complete creeper and wanted nothing more than to have sex with her, she's weirded out by you. Act like just a friend? She gets all weird on you asking why you  didn't  come on to her. Call all of her friends out? She just laughs in your face. Be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ back to her? She stops talking to you. And that's what you want. You don't want her to talk to you, because she's a genuinely terrible human being. On top of that, the main character is a ♥♥♥♥ing cucklord and I hate him, he missed his chance of getting with the decent girl because of his dumb obsession with Emily. I'm not really for a game that's supposed to have moral choices but you can do nothing but wrong because the character who the choices are aimed towards is an insufferable, volatile ♥♥♥♥♥.  If your choices meant something, and Emily wasn't a completely horrible person, it'd be a neat concept. I like the whole idea of a visual novel-esque game set on an early IM chat interface. It's a neat idea. But being honest? 'dont take it personally babe it just aint your story' did a similar thing and did it better because your choices actually MEANT something. And if you complain about Emily being a more realistic character than anyone in that games, yeah it's true, but is she a likeable character? Is she someone you'd spend several years of your life talking to? I know I wouldnt.  Edit: This review got waaay more attention than I expected, so let me address something here. I am NOT mad about being friendzoned in a game. As a straight (mostly) adult woman, why would I care about some fictional woman in a video game made by, to be frank, some beta whiteknight? The game bothers me because it ensues that it is perfectly normal and exceptable to be led on and manipulated by a woman, and that a woman who does this should be given the attention she so craves. Emily is emotionally abusive and she does nothing but gaslight you. If Emily's character was instead a man, people would be outraged by how the character is portrayed. A man can't be as emotionally manipulative as Emily was, that would be seen as you know, ABUSIVE. Which is what Emily is. But instead, the game makes you feel guilty for doing anything wrong to her, because she's a woman. This is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t social agenda. To all the people telling me that it's a reflection of what they dealt with in High School or College and therefore they could relate, jesus christ, I guess you enjoyed being walked all over and not having any self-control. If a girl was treating me like this, I'd drop her instantly. If you see this story as realistic, then that shows the kind of person you are - someone who is easily manipulated. Because to me, in no way, shape or form is this a realistic depiction of a friendship, as anyone with anything going on up there in that old brain of theirs would know to avoid people like Emily, not talk to her for what, 5 years and repeatedly get screwed over by her? tl;dr I'm not mad that I couldn't get any of Emily's roast beef sandwich, more so that the character was portrayed in a way where you were supposed to appease her, no no, respect her even, despite her actions. Because she's a woman. And women are always right, right?

This game is an experience. Not specifically a good one. Not specifically a bad one. Many people may relate to this and feel emotionally attached. Many people won't. The problem with this game is that it doesn't show you backstory of the player and the backstory of Emily. They're friends from what we gather and that's just it. Emily then goes on to get a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ boyfriend, dump him, say we should make out, accuse you of wanting to smash, date ♥♥♥♥♥♥ boyfriend again and ditch you. The real emotion in this game comes with deeper thought. A lot of the other reviews of this game and from my friend's experiences allow me to see that they feel sad as Emily is gone. She's gone forever and you have no way of talking to her again. Even after you cared for her all of these years. That's the problem. WE shouldn't feel sad. WE shouldn't want Emily to come back. She ditched us after all we've done and she should feel bad for doing so.  Yeah, she's gone and we can't speak to her.  Yeah, all those years have gone by.  HOWEVER, when she grows older, she will feel remember us and remember how her boyfriend hurt her and she we be sad.  Only then can we speak to her again; and by this time, things would have changed.  TLDR/CONCLUSION;  This game is interesting. It may come as a sudden shock for people but over time, things will get better. There is a glitter of hope in the end of this game, just as there is one in your life. Yes, I mean you - the reader. If you feel as if you can relate to this game in any way, things will get better. Just give it some time, just as this game would and it'll all end peachy.
More options than Fallout 4   10/Goodbye

I'm pretty sure we bonked once or twice offscreen. I bet that my character went to buy flowers, chocolates, and roofies right after saying goodbye. Gotta go and apologize to Emma for 'making her wait too long'. Well i'm awfully sorry that i only exist ONCE A YEAR in this quantum continuum, Keira Knightley waited for Orlando Bloom at the end of Pirates, you don't even have to wait THIS long. I ain't even Davy Jones. Sheesh.

All we wanted was to love her. We tried everything. We built up her confidence. We picked her up when she fell down. We lifted her spirits. We were, at least I thought we were, soulmates....  ....  I have never been more wrong.  Emily, is without a doubt, the most pathetic and cruel human on the planet. No matter what we did, and no matter what we said, somehow, in Emily's mind, we took advantage of her, even though she is quoted as saying she doesn't regret ANYTHING, nor would take ANYTHING back, we still become the bad guy,..  HOW IS THAT FAIR?!?!?!?!  We tried to rescue her, from an emotionally and possibly physically abusive relationship, with epic toolbag BRAD. Then when she finally comes to her senses and leaves him, she visits us. And that is where it all goes wrong.... NO MATTER WHAT WE DO!  Then, in her delusional mind, she is rescued by EPIC TOOLBAG....BRAD. She treats like a villain, and proclaims BRAD to be the HERO....pshhh. What a load of crap!!!!   We are given NO free will, to truly speak our mind, to let her know how we truly feel about her (aka: WE LOVE HER), and absolutely NO option to win her back. Why give us options to say something, only to take them away, right before our eyes! That is cruelty. We worked up the courage to say it, before a robot from the Matrix came and erased our answers and replaced them with awkward small-talk, made by strangers. This is not even an accurate represenation of real life. You have heartache, but you never give up. You get turned down, but you keep trying, and fighting, and no robot EVER really comes to erase, and then replace your answers.   All in all, it was fun and interesting, and did bring back memories, and left me nostalgic for times past... BUT it left me wanting more. Much, much more. More freedom is needed to make this game more realistic, so that we are at least left with the impression that we can win Emily back. Or at least that we are given the option ourselves to turn down Emily, because quite frankly, she is the worst by the end of the game!   Bye.  Kate is away

Emily is Away is a short game, where you (re)live the good old time of the instant messaging with icons, with horrible sounds. You play Emily's best friend and for 5 or 6 years, you're going to see this relationship evolve depending on your choices during the discussions. You begin at the end of high school until finishing college.  If there is something that you should know is that there is no happy ending. Well, I mean, you can be as nice as you, as much as responsible, trying to please Emily and the result will be always the same: she'll call on you. At the end, you can see that life changed you both.  You can clearly see that your character was crushing on Emily, however, you don't know if she's feeling the same. You don't have any control on outside events, like Travis's party or what happened between you and her during the week-end after she broke up with her boyfriend.  However, it's frustrating to try different routes. Each end of the discussion is Emily is away. You tell her that you can miss a group project reunion, a party with your friends, etc.. so that you can listen to her and she's rejecting this offer for example.  The fact is that Emily is Away is just a game made for nostalgic people. You just press enter to see the text you're writing (even correcting faults) and you choose your answer just before among three proposed. Some of them will not change the course of the discussion, others are important.  The only real fun thing to do is to try many usernames, to unlock new icons. I would even say that some may be not belonging to this era at all (Portal, Undertale and others). Another funny thing is to look at everyone's profile and remember when you were putting quotes or lyrics everywhere.  But it's not because it may become boring after a while that Emily is Away isn't worth a shot. It's reflecting life as it can happen, missed opportunities and relationships. It's always interesting to see that and besides, like I've said, it's also for nostalgic people, though I'm not feeling a nostalgia wave.  The graphics aren't bad at all. It's really well-chosen for what the game will want to do. As for the soundtrack, apart the infamous Windows sound and the ping, you don't have anything.  My only problem is that the cursor isn't pointing on where you want, I needed to click on the left of a button to manage to play - it has caused me a problem the first time I've played it as I thought it was stuck. I suppose it's a problem due to the a wider monitor than the game can handle.  Emily is Away is a good little game in the end and as it's free, your wallet will not cry for money.
Best teenage guy simulator 2000  10 out of 10
No matter what choices you make, the game always ends the same way.

Maybe about two hours long if you are really slow at finding all the endings. You barely have any control over the story since most of the options are either the same thing or lead to the same dialog.  Emily is boring with no interesting traits other than being an angsty collage student. Everyone else has nothing (other than your character who from the dialog options is assumed to be a total beta).   The ending is supposed to be 'realistic' but all of the characters are so borring and get so little development you just don't care.   Gameplay itself was just chosing an option and mashing your keyboard until it typed it out so you could send (which got old quick).  The graphics are badly designed in that they made it pixel art for some reason instead of just trying to imitate XP.  The only 'fun' part in this 'game' was picking your avatar and name and watching how she reacts.   I don't know if you can even call this a game. I mean, at least in VNs you can have bad endings! If you want a branching story, play a VN or a telltale game. This is a waste of 40 minutes.

first of all. id like to take the time to make you understand there is no 'winner' in this game its a text based linear game that revolves around a converstation between you and a girl known as Emily as you progress thoughout the mid 2000's your friendship with emily changes. Decisions you make do not matter, schools you choose do not matter. basically anything you DECIDE to do doesnt matter beacuse the next chapter you do has the same basic plots. You know its game over before its game over, and that ruins the fun. there is not a single way to WIN this game. without spoiling to much of the game, dont think this game is a dating sim, dont think for a second that Emily and [PLAYER] wind up together in a happy-go-lucky relationship.  if by reading this review spoils anything or prevents you from downloading it, then sorry, but this game is a 1 play through game. Trust me, there are no alternate endings. you got what everyone else gets..   if by chance in the last chapter you manage to get Emily to sign off before you, (which can be done, its not hard)  i would personally consider that the best win possible    if your looking for a quick nostaligic game (that actually DID accurately portray what i was like during those years) than i suppose this game is for you    in terms of everything else, i would NOT recommend.   and to the developer  Emily is Away had potential to be an actually very fun game. I know that this game was probably made with a little hard work and time, and for that I give you kudos   I know how difficult coding games are, beleive me I do I know that making alternate choices and paths are not the easiest thing in the world, as it requires more time and code.  but i also know that if you DID choose to make it more open ended, or have alternative choices, maybe even 3 more, then i would have probabaly had something better to say about it.  I know my one review means little to nothing but i just dont want other players to get the wrong impression about the game   Kyle Seeley, im sorry if this story (or something similar) happened to you in person. It happens. I know all to well what it was like back then, trying to express feelings to someone, and trying to maintain contact when two peoples lives are so busy and seperated. I hope that if something like this DID happen, that you have found someone to enjoy your life with who is ALOT better than Emily ever could be.   Thanks for reading  TL:DR  Messenger Game that makes you want to shoot the Messenger

It made me even more mad, because I felt it was SHE who was being pushy about coming out for the weekend. She was obviously on the rebound.      I don't know, maybe teens will get more appreciation from this game. Maybe even some adults.   This is just one of the most disatisfying waste of time games I've played to date. On the plus side, I got all of the achievements in 40 minutes.

If you just want to be her friend she will go back to her douch*bag boyfriend after a while - she must really love the 'd'. Ok AIM simulator, bland though.   Biggest dissapointment is the single ending no matter what choices you make. The games is a missed opportunity, narrativly.   I also felt the game's portrayal of the titular emily was, honestly, sexist and stereotypical.  Well made enough to fool me though, so I played through three times trying for a different outcome. The mechanics, UI, and easter eggs were thoughtful and well implemented.  I'm still going with not reccommended, because there are way better games in the same style that have better story and characters. Check out this person's next project, because they are on the right track, but skip this one.

I really enjoyed this game. It gives a really good view into a teen's brain and how they both grow into real adults. It is very real in the sense that people are messy, they make mistakes, they go through loves and losses and sometimes barely miss eachother in the process, and I liked that there was not a 'good' or happy ending. Life doesn't always just work out. It's hard and it's messy and we break into pieces sometimes. I look forward to seeing more from this dev!

A truly touching and depressing story that will take you on a roller coaster ride all the way through. You start as a High School senior in the 00s, who uses AIM for kicks to talk with his friends, I don't know how they got away with using the AIM graphics. It is the end of your highschool life. You and your friends would like to celebrate, as any average youthful adults would. You and Emily discuss going to the party, but there is this prickly sore in your side named Brad, Brad has been flirting with Emily on the internet. Watch as you make the worst ♥♥♥♥ing descisions possible, watch as you ♥♥♥♥♥ out with certain dialogue choices. Will you end up with Emily? Will Brad sexually coerce her? Will it all end in flames? Will you kiss her? Will you choose to ♥♥♥♥ her? I won't give anything away, but the fact there is a very emotionally touching yet simple ending and we all learn that we have known girls in our youth like Emily. Overall, I say try it, It is really deep and well done for a free to plane online dating sim type game. I'd reccomend you play it just for the plot and emotional experience of it all. As a FTP 9/10, as an actual game, 7.4/10

It's a fun, small, free to play game where your choices influence the outcome. It throws you back in time and clearly shows how people can grow away from one another after high school.   One thing though: You play a guy. I'm not a guy, and having these talks with Emily were extremely weird since none of them seemed to be natural to me. Jealousy and love are not common concepts in a girl-to-girl talk. Of course there are exceptions, but these fictional characters seem to only be interested in the opposite gender. This just made for a really awkward and forced storyline. It felt more like a teen drama to me, one that I would stay far away from personally, but it was still fun.

I can't wholeheartedly recommend this game even though I enjoyed my time with it. It's a super novel idea that makes you take a nostalgic walk down memory lane for sure, but the game just seems to give you an illusion of choice.   The story is all this game is and it takes the TellTale-esque 'Will remember that' blurb that seemingly has no impact on any choices you make. You're still funneled to the same ending, which don't get me wrong is good, but it's a far cry from a 'branching narrative'.  The act of playing this game actually made my hands hurt. You have to 'type' out your responses but they hardly ever line up with the preview so all in all it just feels tedious with little substance. I found myself just drumming my fingers on the keyboard trying to get to the next choice.   All in all this is a nice 20 minute experience but it has no replay value due to the lack of varied endings.   2/5

Being free, this game really depends on how much you value your time. But, I think most people can relate to this game.  The ending is kind of poetic. This game, unlike real life, allows you to go back and try different conversations and play them out. Without giving anything away, I think the way they all play out is somewhat brilliant. It might give people some closure/insight as to how relationships have changed over time -- is it because of something you said in your online conversations?  There's a lesson from this game, at least I took something from it. In the end, it's probably best to actually *talk* to people if you care about rather than AIM them once a year.

It was good for what it is; I definetly believe it deserves a little bit more attention. it's a short, clever game that tugs at your heart strings a bit and might even strike up some nostalgia in you! If you have some free time, give it a try. If you decide to, go through with all of it; meaning it's best to be started and finished in one sitting. Not to mention you can knock out all 20 achievments in about 20 minutes :] Most in the form of fun little easter eggs.

Wow.  Wow is the first word that came to my head when I finished Emily Is Away. The game is really unique and gives that emotional experience everyone really needs. This game is going to be recommended to all my friends. A great game if you love simple, yet emotional rides you never want to get off of.

First Play: I was the sensative guy friend who's always there. I never tried to hit that when she was on the rebound. Friendzone.  Second Play: Complete a-hole. Called everything and everyone in her life crappy. Friendzone.  Third Play: An in-between guy. Calls out some crap, yet is there for his friend. Decided not to let her come over on the rebound for fear something could go down that would screw things up. Felt like crap for not 'Being there' when I promised I would and still Friendzoned.   Cried myelf to sleep that night.   8/10  Pros: It was a quick and easy game, so you feel good about yourself when you finished it quickly. It was very well put together to make it seem like it was AIM messenger, a bunch of different icons in reference to pop culture of each year, I could have inappropriate usernames and not get kicked off or banned because I used a certain five letter word that starts with P.  Cons: It isn't really a complete 'point and click' because you have to use the keyboard to 'type' the messages out. By that I mean I more or less ran my hands back and forth on the keyboard and somehow I still typed complete sentances. I got bored easily. It was REAAAALLLY easy for me to get new icons by just changing my username to 'Zelda' or something. The chapters were very short. It made it seem like the lives of these two people literally paused for an entire year until the next time they talked to each other.    Extra Pro: I rocked out to 'Dragon Slayer' by NSP while playing this game
First ever time an AOL chat has depressed me. 10/10 would IM again. Seriously, considering it's free, this is a game worth downloading immediately.

Basically, if you want to simulate your teen years trying to suck up to a <female dog> that puts you on an emotional rollercoaster, then play this game. I understand it could be considered a reflection of a real life story, but this is a story with no real...resolution. Is the resolution is to somehow stop yourself from being conned into these waste-of-time relationships? But you would never know it hurt until you got into one yourself and had some great experiences. So should you avoid all relationships altogether to completely eliminate that chance? Not quite...  ...I think it more or less shatters the expectation that the one you think will be with you forever is meant to be with you. There is no ONE person, and statistically there are probably several different viable candidates (even based on your picky 'ol criteria!). I mean look at the side character Emma or whoever it is you end up hanging out with at college. What the <H-E -Double Hockey Sticks> was wrong with her? Did she die? Seems like you had buttloads of fun with her!  Maybe when I have gone through the thick of these teen/young adult years I will come out with a better resolution, but perhaps this is what the author meant:   It is best that you go away sometimes  , that you set the pace for your life and that emotional attachments, like most other things, can be transient in this world. But don't let this get you down, it may be worth it to love after all, and we are social creatures. I wish you the best of luck with this.  4.5/5 Heart Containers

WARNING: THERE IS NO GOOD ENDING TO THIS GAME!!! ONLY GET THIS GAME IF YOU WANT A FREE GAME TO PAD OUT BADGES AND ACHIEVEMENTS WITH!  I'll recommend it for being a free game that gives achievements (stat padding, yay!) and trading cards, but this is more of a kinetic novel than a visual novel. Your choices don't change things in any meaningful way. If you DO try to do a playthrough of an honest, trying-to-succeed relationship with her, you'll get friend-zoned at best (it's up in the air as to whether you remain friends or not). Even if you try to just remain friends with Emily, you'll still get kicked to the 'this is weird between us, are we still friends?' curb.  so, obligatory list:  PROS: 1. it's free 2. It's easily 'completed' achievement-wise, for padding your games-completed percentage 3. it has trading cards for SHINY SHINY BADGES!!! Myyyy PRRRECIOUUUUSSSS.....  4. Interesting story mechanic and storyline, so long as you don't mind your choices never really mattering  CONS: 1. It's more of a kinetic novel than a virtual novel (a subtype of virtual novel where player does not interact with the story... referenced here because the choices don't really affect gameplay at all, and has no change in anything other than filler-fluff) 2. There is no good ending, only your choice of bad (since the game revolves around you and Emily, and it ends with your friendship in question (at best) EVERY time; Therefore, no good ending) 3. NO skip-mode, you have to hold down a button to 'type' the entire time, and remember to hit ENTER. Makes trying for multiple playthroughs very very annoying.

This game is simple. You are thrown back in the early 2000's, there's a girl called Emily that you start to get attached to and you start to text her. The game covers the texting parts of your relationship in a brilliant way. The nostalgia of using Windows XP to talk to a crush I had back in school days hits the player really hard as the game simulates a system based on that Microsoft system. The relationship between the two of you start to grow and reaching new levels. There will always be 3 different reply options that you can choose, even though the outcome of the events will be pretty much the same. I won’t give you any spoilers but what I can tell is that this game has a very powerful message once it is completed. It took me a while to put the pieces together and get what the game was actually all about. That’s all I can say. Play it. It’s a free-to-play game on Steam that is 100% worth all the time and patience put into it as long as you keep your mind open.  90/100

What a trip down memory lane. This game is going to be a memorable experience for anyone who grew up during the heyday of the AOL chats (from the late 90s to the early 2000s). Our generation was one of the first where technology played a such a huge role in our socialization into young adults. This game succeeds not in its presentation, but in its ability to tap into the emotions of a simpler time; a time when we were developing our identities, and trying forge our futures with a sense of hopeful optimism.  The game consists of a series of instant message conversations over a 5 year period with a friend by the name of “Emily.” Without giving away too many details, the game’s dialogue is an emotional rollercoaster that almost any American millennial will be able to relate with. Emotions such as the the thrill of having your first “best friend” of the opposite sex, the jealousy of jilted love, and the anxiety of confessing one’s feelings are all skillfully woven into the game’s dialogue. At the end of this game, one can’t help but empathize with the protagonist, and relate the character of Emily to someone from their own past. It could be someone that you felt strongly about, but that for one reason or another, did not admit your feelings toward.  What impressed me about this game was not the mechanics or presentation of it. At the end of the day, it is simply a free-to-play game, with limited content, and a relatively basic plotline. However, it is the creative genius behind the concept itself, and the game’s ability to evoke such strong emotions in the player, that make this a memorable title. I would really like to see this developer expand upon this title, or even create other IM-based game experiences. This is an exploration into a new genre of gaming, much in the same way that Dear Esther, Gone Home, and Her Story charted new territory.  Give this game a try, and you might be pleasantly surprised. The pleasure comes not from the experience itself, but from your reflection of the experience.

This was a good game, even if it feels unfinished. The interface is clever and gives you a stronger vibe of talking to a real person than SmarterChild or CleverBot, even if Emily's dialogue has no real AI behind it. My only real problem is the plot; as I said, this game feels unfinished, as it's over incredibly fast and every play through feels the same in spite of making different choices. My hope is that this game is a starting point, and that an expanded version comes out later with far more choices (that have more noteworthy consequences) and that chronicles more than just a couple of years. I'd like to see this game follow Emily and the player through several decades of their lives -- or, perhaps, keep it limited to the college timespan, but allow for more interactions to give the player's choices more opportunities to change their relationship.  One other thing: The game never really announces before you play it that you're a guy that's pining away for Emily, so figuring that out while playing was a little jarring to me, as I'd been playing as a female friend. I'd either make this clearer at the onset so the player can enter with the right frame of mind, expand the conversation options so it's not trying so hard to steer the player in that direciton, or broaden the game entirely and allow the player to decide from the start who and what they are to Emily. This game is primarily about a relationship, and that can still be examined whether we assume the role of this one specific guy or not.  In any case, none of these qualms were enough to make me not play. The game is free, so give it a peek and experience it for yourself. You can literally get through the game in about 10 minutes, so anyone and everyone can find an opportunity to give it a try. It's a nice little gaming experiment.

Initially I was welcomed with some deep nostalgia. As a free game, it does a good job of drawing you into the early 2000's era of Windows XP Live Messenger/MySpace era.  For those who remember socializing over the internet as a kid, and potentially getting romantically involved, it will probably strike a few buttons. Especially with the recurring themes.  The game is centred around a fictional character named Emily, depending on how you talk to her, she will respond to you and things will play out differently.  Dialogue options are almost always the same apart from pre-defined branches. Which really stops its replay value. You have to get through a lot of rubbish to get to different branches.  It's pretty stupid how it chooses to automatically put you in the shoes of an American sophomore, as an Australian I couldn't relate to that, or the college theme.  But hey, it's a free game. Free nostalgia hit. Give it a go if you're over 20 years old. If you're younger, you won't get the same rush.

Amazing game, must play. Weird that I selected 'no,' huh? Well, that's because it's wasted potential. It's original, and I love choose your path games, but the only problem is that there is only one ending. Those choices you made all through the game got you a bad ending? Oh well, just replay and get a better one. SURPRISE! There's only one ending. All those carefully thought out choices you made didn't matter. they all lead to the same thing. It's not an interactive story, it's just a story.

Umm.....No. I don't recommend this. Maybe for free achievements, but was the experience something enjoyable? No. This game essentially proves that statements like 'I'll always be there for you', 'You'll always be my best friend', and 'We're still friends' mean absolutely nothing.   Two teenage friends talk, but you essentially watch the end of a friendship.    Your crush gets a BF, you play the jealousy game, you visit, you grow distant, and you essentially end your friendship by growing distant from one another    Sure, the game seems like an interactive where you get to choose your route, but you'll always come back to the same ending. Now, Emily does 'remember' options you choose and will bring them up later, but it doesn't change what ending you get.  I've seen similar stories played many times throughout my life and they're people I realize were never people I should have trusted. People I should have never even met. People that I feel my life would have been better if I had never heard of these people....but those are stories for another time. This simply reminds me too much of my own past, showing how little you can rely on somebody...   PROS: Achievements AIM nostalgia of Windows XP days No bugs and programmed decently Free  CONS: Boring A friend who doesn't know what she wants Death of a friendship Depressing ending as you essentially watch it all rot away   Despite it being a free game, I only recommend this for the free, easy achievements. The bonus icon achievements have some nice in-jokes, but that's about it. As far as the story itself goes, you might want to pass. Nostalgic and well-programmed text game, but not something that I enjoyed playing. Sometimes the past should stay burried.   2/10. (Emily, just go away and stay away. Best friend my *ss... 'I'll always be there for you' means nothing.)

It is worth the $0 price, and the ~20 minutes of time to play it through at least once.  I'd give this game 3 'Goodbye.'s out of 3.   MY HEART IS NOT A PLAYTHING EMILY.      And ♥♥♥♥ you Brad.

Wow. If you've ever had a chat conversation with someone you were just friends with, but who you really liked a lot more.. then 'Emily Is Away' will likely make you feel right at home!  You are obviously trying to win Emily's heart, or this game makes you feel like that anyhow.. and it does a damn good job at making you feel it. The chat responses, questions, and topics are VERY believable. At points, it almost doesn't feel like you're playing a game, lol. I was surprised how interesting it was and how curious I was to see how my choices for responses to 'Emily' caused this game to end! ..I can see why this game is so popular now, with over 3,500 reviews in just two days on Steam! It's pretty darn good!  Sooo, can YOU get the girl? I would definitely play again because Brad got Emily and I'm not real happy! LOL! 9.5/10!

So, this game is a huge release for 2015 - and in my opinion it has to be one of the best releases of 2015, firstly the graphics were insane, I couldn't believe it when I saw the graphics load up in Ultra quality, it was truly amazing for my eyes and I couldn't believe what I was actually seeing, this game has a huge amount such as a desktop toolbar with up to 2 applications and even has a clock in the bottom right corner which is a huge gameplay feature, the engine on this game is also worth mentioning as i've never seen one like it, it has a smooth and slick engine that is yet to be outmatched by any releases and in my opinion it was a solid 10/10 compared to games like Fallout 4, GTA 5, and Black Ops 3 as the engines on those games were shocking. I don't understand how this is actually free too! insane right? it's like all of my wishes for a new release were rolled up into one and combined to create this.  The storyline? well I found that the NPC's that you would meet had such a variety, and the best thing? you can say up to THREE things to them, and the best thing is you can use a keyboard to type the replies out as if you're actually typing, the storyline was long and epic, many crazy things happened and the amount of plot twists was amazing, you didn't know what would come round the corner at any time, and the epic intensity of typing out a message and not knowing if the main NPC 'emerly35' would respond nicely or eternally hate you for savagely destroying her self confidence, it was honestly so insane and amazing as I was on the edge of my seat around every single turn of and unravel of this epidemic of a storyline, this game has done so much for me, it even made my mom think I actually had some sort of social life.  Pros:  Everything.  Cons: NPC 'emerly35' is sometimes away.   Overall this game was an epidemic and whilst writing this review I was struggling to remember the best things because there are far too many, so I do apologise if this review was short.

All in all, this isn't a bad pick up, especially for free.   However, out of necessity for a gameplay review, it's not worth much more than free - and that's perfectly fine. On the first playthrough, the narrative is compelling and choices definitely matter... it's after the first playthrough where things start falling apart.  It becomes cascadingly clear that, as with many (if not all) 'choices matter' titles there is actually very little deviation from plot points across playthroughs representing different choices. Is that a crime? Not necessarily, at least for a free game. Though I feel it must be pointed out - if only to throw in an objective opinion.  So why the positive review? The game does wonders in conveying emotion and even themes and morals if the player is looking for it. Standard $60 titles are picked up for their playability. Indie releases such as this are picked up for their impact on the player. Without sounding too pretentious, I enjoy a game infinitely more if it successfully incorporates meaning and intent seamlessly into it.   So yes, its worth the playthrough, but not because it's bringing new life to the 'choices matter' genre.

Your choices don't matter and this can hardly be called a branching narrative, the only thing that branched was if Emily dated one of two people she met at the party, both of which have identical influence on the story, being rude, breaking up with her then getting back together and going to a concert. Other than that its hard to feel sentimental for text on a screen that you only talk to once a year and you know little about, its just 'presumed you were friends up to 2002'. At later points in the game your choice of A, B or C will sometimes be erased completely, what's that, you want Emily to visit this weekend? Nope you get 'Doing any homework?'. Could not be further away from what I asked.  Feel free to play through this once, don't expect much out of it, no real reason to play any more than that.

I would give this game a 6/10 as I feel a five is to low and would do it an injustice but anything more would be overlooking it's down sides. Now let's review the pros and cons of Emily is Away  Pros: -Customization options allowing you to feel more like the character your controlling a simple thing but it's nice.  -Immersive and relatabe story through the awkward times most people face between highschool and college.  -feels.buckets.of.feels.  -nostalgic sounds of computers that bring you back to a simpler time.  -good charcter development on emily,brad,travis,and the protagonist.  -so many easter eggs to movies and music.  -short but well written and doesn't overstay it's welcome  -it's free and it's pretty small size wise.and if you don't enjoy it you can always just delete it but it's definitely worth a try.  Cons: -you know that game until dawn..yeah this isn't that game your choices esentially don't matter ,no matter what college you go to your going to end up meeting mike and emma,no matter how you treat emily she's not gonna date you,and no matter what the game ends with you deleting your true feelings to ask trivial ♥♥♥♥ til you can only say good bye.  -would have liked to be able to talk to some of the other people on my friends list like mike,brad,or emma to solidify the plot more and make it more in depth  - logic lapses my character doesn't seem to know brad yet brad is clearly on my characters friends list since year one was is he just there for  convienence,sake?  Same with Mike and Emma who I supposedly 'met in college'. My character also clearly no longer talks to travis but his name remains in the game infinitely and we watch as he seems to spiral downward into depression and yet we never mention this even though he was supposedly our friend back in high school.  -little to no development on mike and emma. How am I supposed to have a crush on a girl I barely know?  -The development Emma does have makes her eerily similar to Emily....Is my character a stalker am I obssessed with girl who like coldplay and snow patrol? It feels an awful lot like he's trying to replace Emily yet in most scenarios that feels really ooc.  -feels.buckets.of.feels.  -no trigger warning to protect those of a depressive nature from the feel buckets.  -protagonist automatically sabotages your final talk with emily and their is nothing you can possibly do to stop him...enjoy reliving those heart breaking moments where you to couldn't say how you really felt.  -...did i mention the feels?!?! they are for reals...seriously I need sobbing advisory for this game because that ending ;m;  - despite what you may think it has very limited replay value  All in all it was a good game ,a good way to spend an hour or so and is certainly worth the few seconds it takes to download. I daresay it's one of the better single player ftp games available on steam i'd put it in the top 20% of games of it's kind. So keep up the great work :)

Completable within about half an hour, Emily is Away is an interesting piece of interactive fiction, but ultimately provides nothing insightful. There are choices that you can make but in much the same vein as those telltale games, the choices only provide differences that skirt around the core plot. In the end, the game has a message to tell you and despite your best intentions, it will strive to deliver it. Whether you can appreciate that message is the deciding factor in whether or not you will enjoy this game.

For a Young me, It was MSN messenger, for a young me, it was a girl named Jessica.   I think a lot of us in this generation know the feeling this game puts forth, From the way we have things we so want to say but chicken out at the last minute, to how it is to finally give up on that person on the other side of the screen, We've all had that friend. The game captures the feeling of that person you wanted to be close to so much, but couldn't quite forge that bond. It's a good, nostalgic story.  The game is a lot like Digital: A love Story for a generation later than the BBS kids. I don't feel that the story here has quite as much thought and care put into it as that one did, but it stands pretty well on it's own right.  That said, the game isn't much of a game, to be honest. It's a choose your own adventure game, but your choices have minimal impact on the story and there is only one ending in the long run, but if you want to have a nice half hour to kill, to remember that one friend we all used to have. Go ahead, It's free, and chances are pretty good you'll feel something for it. *ZeonTwilight is Away.

Emily is Away is a game about your time from High School senior year to College senior year, chronicling your once-a-year IM conversation with a girl named Emily. The game's writing is pretty poor, however, because in every instance that you talk to Emily she'll blame SOMEONE ELSE for her life's problems instead of herself, based on your dialogue choices from the previous year. No matter what, every year will be worse than the previous between you and Emily and even when you go out of your way to make things go well, it just won't. No matter what options you pick, it will end the same way in the final year. The game has no GOOD ending, it has only one ending. Perhaps the author intended for you to only play through it only once, which is why every route goes the same way in the end, so no one could correlate all the endings together like I did .. but...  What are some pros? -The game emulates AOL Instant Messenger (AIM) down to a tee, from sound effects to colours and appearance -It can seem like a nice nostalgic trip back to your years in high school (assuming you're close to 30 and actually know what AIM was) -The typing mechanic seems like a nice touch -I guess you could say the game is gender neutral in that the random button for names has both male and female names, so Emily and Emma are bisexual  So what are some cons? -The plot is a static line, no matter what, the plot is always the same -The typing mechanic wears its novelty out really quick, and there's no way to autotype -The game betrays the player's agency by changing the entire context of options you choose, changing dialogue from your intention to the all-encompassing binary choice system that in the end boils down to the same ending -you'll never succeed -for some reason both love interests have their names starting with Em which could be confusing for a listener if you're trying to explain the plot to someone  In the end, I just can't recommend this. I've played a bunch of VNs and text adventure games, but in most games your choices have SOME effect. Other than minor changes in the dialogue, the game ends the same. While typing this, I thought to myself 'maybe I just had to choose this option differently, maybe it's because I chose the tech school?' so I loaded it up just to change that, it didn't make a difference. Your character shows a lackluster approach to life where they can't even type with grammar or proper spelling, and in the end, you always end up with the same crappy ending.  Don't bother playing this unless you want to read a really lousy short story observing a character you'll grow to depise in no time at all.

Before I played I felt uneasy about the inaccuracy of the trailer, it makes Emily look like a time traveller. But I was relieved there were no such errors in the actual game. I also liked how some of the buddy infos changed depending on your choises.

Emily, the main aspect of this story, is ultimately a boring character, and even though she was admittedly well written, it was still very unengaging to interact with her. Also, the endings are very dumb, which means that the build up isn't even worth it.  However, I will say it was well made.

Emily is away was a great, then boring, then a great experience again for me.  **SPOILER ALERT**  The games controls are pretty weird as you can just type whatever you want while the character types the actual message. I found a meta game in trying to type the same letter he was going to type before he typed it.   But that's not the point.  Towards the very end of the game, there are plenty of opportunities that you have to tell emily your true feelings (to me they seemed a little needy, 'Do you ever miss me?') and when you select for your character to tell her the true feelings you have, the character begins typing the message you intended. However, he will then erase the message and enter his own small talk, asking how the weather is or if she's seen any good movies lately. This seems very frustrating to players because we are in a very saturated industry with games where 'Choice changes the game!!' and little decisions do change a little piece of the game, but the outcome is always the same in the end, emily leaves, and you never get your chance with her.  So why do I recommend this game? Well the way I felt during the game, was that I was my character's desires.. His mind, i suppose. I would tell him what to say, and he would type it, sometimes not even the way I worded it. That's where it gets interesting at the end of the game. I tell my character to tell Emily he misses the way they used to be, and he types it, then erases it because he's scared. I'm left thinking to myself 'You idiot! You're ruining your chance!!' But that is when I realized that the character I believed I was controlling must be thinking the exact same thing. Sometimes in life your whole being wants to do something, and yet, you just don't do it. Whether it's asking that person out on a date, taking that risk on a dream job, or whatever else.  That is why I like the game, that is why I recommend it to anyone who is looking for an interesting narrative and a new look at the art of video games.  Overall? 7/10. The game didn't blow my mind, but I really liked the direction it got my mind to take.

Emily is Away is a short game, simply. However for it being completely free, what's to lose? Sure it may be small but you have a lot of interaction between you and Emily. It also informs you when changes in the dialogue and story in a TellTale Games sort of manner with a 'She will remember that' or 'You have decided to ________'. So straight to the point- is Emily is Away a genre defining game with groundbreaking mechanic. No. Is this game a solid game with a human atmosphere? Yes. In fact, the story is like a ball of clay completelly, the only differance being with a mound of clay- you start with nothing, with this game you start best freinds with Emily. But due to how life is you must try harder to stay friends.  Overall Emily is Away is a solid Telltale game sort of game with a great athmoshere 8/10

Honestly the concept for this game is a great way to have a visual novel game. It also has that nostalgia factor with AIM, Windows sounds, and the icons relating to music, movies, etc of the time (I would recommend not doing the secret icons until after going through the game once).   The execution wasn't perfect however. It would have been nice to be able to interact with some of the other characters and adding some more weight to my choices. In the end though the game is free and I enjoyed the hour or so I spent with it and the 'ending' I got had me relating to some friendships I had with people over AIM in the past so good job to the creator for being able to do that.   If this was a paid product I would expect so much more, would be neat to see this concept expanded upon in the future.

There's some cute cold-reading going on here. Think about it.   You can go further than even just the scope of the average Steam user: survey Young People Who Use Computers in general, and there's probably nearly a 100% probable chance that:   1. They attended a high school with at least one, probably two Emily(s). It has literally been proven to be the most common white girl name in the world; actual scientists confirmed it.  2. They used a computer with a windows operating system that had some kind of crappy free messenger software: either MSN or AIM, probably.  3. They were - and are probably still are - bad at talking to girls.  So, honestly, it's really confusing to me how people don't understand the sort of point of the game. Maybe people are just very resistant to seeing any kind of resemblance of themselves in the black mirror (I know it's a cute metaphor for a computer screen, leave me alone.)  If anything, it's just a fun little adventure to play through a few times to explore the different reactions and responses, and then feel sad as you realise that the whole point was that you weren't really supposed to get any agency or closure anyway. The Walking Dead is basically the same thing, except that they paid a whole bunch of people to hide the basic choose-your-own-adventure engine under all the graphics and sad music and zombie gore, and even in spite of all that work you can only really play through it maybe twice.   You can probably play this maybe even three times before you get bored! At least!

It's an okay idea, but it's not worth playing more than once, or at all.  Honestly if you've read the other reviews than you don't need to read mine as almost everyone has experienced the same thing. However, just in case you want to read this. for some reason, I guess I'll go on.   This game does have a good idea. It is a game based on reliving a higher education experience which is backed up with a retro art style and older pop culture. However the new idea ends there and everything else is pretty much standard dating sim gameplay with the exception of the part where you date the person. I personally didn't mind that and at time of writting I am not sure if there are ways to earn an ending that allows that. There is dating, but not for you and emily.  There are a few problems i have with the game. For one there are several ways to play with several endings, which is a good or bad thing based on you perspective, but what annoyed me is that there are several stories; this caused Emily to have a different personality between the stories and being hypocritical in some playthroughs as well as completely unlikeable. The main problem is that having too many stories makes it unavoidable to have a few desrepancies.  Overall, dull game that just becomes frustrating the more you play it. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who doesn't want to waste their time.

A surprising and engaging game. As I had no real expectations as to what I getting into it was nice to, if only for a very brief time, (the game is not long) be totally sold on this world and the character of Emily. It is difficult to think she is not real or indeed for a time that I had not been whisked back to my own univeristy years and partaking in a real online messenger conversation with a dear friend. I can see much potential with this, although perhaps any follow up would not hold qute the same level of captivation as this. As a free to play there is no real reason to not give this a go, especialy as it will likely only steal 30 minutes of your time. I am keen to try a few replays though to see if I can get a reactive ending from my choices, though I would not be too upset if that is not the case. Indeed this is such a simple and unique offering that whether or not it can be classified as a game seems unimportnat to its true worth.

I guess it's ok for a free to play game, but the whole thing is just depressing and stupid.  Emily is an annoying girl who throws all her problems at you, Blames you for certain things and trys to 'play the victim' all the time.  Brad and Travis are the same person. Emma is a girl... That's about it... And worst of all, your character (who you are forced to play as) is a creepy, lonely, sad stalker who has nothing better to do that stare at his chat window. I hate how this game ended and that the branching paths are like 2 branches that constantly reconnect. Don't waste your time making yourself feel miserable.

This is a game that really encapsulates how relationships change over time. From when you were young and had feelings for someone but were too afraid to tell them, to the time that you realize the relationship of any sort has been dead for a while, and they have no desire to maintain it.  Some people have said Emily is a bad or unlikable person, but I think it's more about how two people can have different perspectives on what has taken place. If you get into the mindset of her being someone you're already invested in, then everything actually works out in a very realistic way.  Normally I would say a game should make you care, but the framing device of the messenger actually really helps get you into that mindset. You mash keys as though you're actually typing, and the dialogue choices, while nothing too complex, cover enough options for you to reply in a way you would naturally. Most natural is when you see yourself delete what you really mean to put in something that will be better recieved. It's actually fairly immersive.  The writting is solid, and I think pretty much everybody can relate. You may not have had the same exact experience, but the emotions it elicites will bring back memories. The game isn't a technical masterpiece, and it doesn't have a ton of interaction with the player, but it is something different. You may want to replay and see the other options, but I opted to live with the choices I had made, just like in real life. After all, it's all about perspective; there really were no right or wrong options in the game, just messages and experiences that were different.   The game is free and only takes half an hour of your time, give it a shot.

This game was beyond dope.  The goal of the game is to get the girl of your dreams (which in this story is Emily). You start off as a high school senior and progress through your college years as you attempt to win Emily over. And while I won't spoil the game's ending, I will say that it's a really powerful conclusion. The only negative aspects of this game are that it's super short and that whatever choices you make will not influence the game's ending. But overall, it's free and it's fantastic.   Positives: +Screw paying, it's free +It only takes up 512mb +Emotional storyline +Simplistic and nostalgic throwback to the 2000s +Emotionally-charged ending  Negatives: -Extremely short game -Only one ending; Choices do not ultimately influence ending  SCORE: 9/11 Would go on this feels trip again.

Great atmosphere, but I feel like the game has a lot of untapped potential. The biggest problem is that it never establishes Emily as an interesting or likeable character. You don't seem to have much in common, or much going on besides each other.  Expanding the scope of the game would probably make it a lot more compelling. Conversations with other characters would give you a life outside of one girl, and give everything perspective. The nostalgia aspect of the game is its strongest point. Even if the story is driven by your relationship with Emily, it'd be nice to have content outside of that.

Lastly, I found the typing mechanic cool for the first few minutes, but it soon became more of a gimmick by the end. Solid premise executed well enough to keep me interested for the upcoming sequel.

**NO TL:DR, that's what my thumbs up is for* A visual novel like game with multiple choices of answers for every response of your character. Heavily inspired by the old days with AOL Instant Messanger, you follow the story of 'Yourself' and a girl named Emily. You go through 5 chapters that span 5 years (each real conversation is a chapter/year) and the tale of 2 friends from high school growing up. Interestingly enough, the player interacts by typing random characters in the keyboard with 'Yourself' typing his response. Now as the game progresses you can view certain people's profiles throughout the chapters to expand the world of friends that you live in.  Without spoiling anything as that's for the bottom because someone knows I need to release my feelings for this great title, it's definitely worth playing/reading through one time with straight up honest decisions. If you want to have some emotional or heart break type of moments or in general are an experimental type, I'd definitely re-read with a different mindset at all times.  --Finally, half-spoilerish (not really), I truly haven't made a grammar mistake in the review, even though it may seem as such--    **************SPOILERS AHEAD, STAY AWAY UNTIL YOU'VE PLAYED THE GAME ONCE*************  Such an interesting tale of 2 friends growing apart, and while in the review I may have sounded like I had alot on my mind, I really don't. The game is so interesting and mysterious, with times where you really feel that you the PLAYER not 'Yourself' is left in the dark or atleast feel something is going on behind the scenes. I'd only like to close out this review or my thoughts on this title with a very depressing or 'philisophical' sort of observation. On my third playthrough, I decided to full out try my hardest to win Emily, and in the end, as I had struggled to respond, 'Youself' kept changing it and kept readjusting it. All my attempts were futile, until in the end 'Yourself' had forced me to say goodbye, that's when I had finally realized something. You truly are looking into the eyes of somebody else, but the game gives you alot of choices at the beginning to fool you, but then as the person begins to give himself an identity he starts to change into a certain mindset. Then everything becomes futile.. Until you decide to leave, '[You] is away'. The only real reason I didn't say this observation is because it's an obvious spoiler and I truly enjoyed nicking the character as 'Yourself' because it feels like it, but it definitely isn't you...

Emily is Away is a beautiful game about a character that you play, but not necessarily have full control over, and a girl named Emily. At its heart the game is about change, as you go year by year, chapter by chapter, you see Emily holding on to the the past, whilst she talks about everyone else changing. Although this game is extremely short, with only about 30 minutes of real gameplay and not much replayabilty, it is sweet, thought-provoking and emotional. Combine this with, what I like to call, the fake typing mechanic, it becomes an interactive experience. The only improvement I could ask for is for your choices to have more of an impact on the ending, but that is one short-coming that can be completely ignored. All in all, this is a short, sweet and powerful game, that definitely has become a must play.

Sometimes, simplicity is best.  It's been a while since a game has hit me on this level emotionally. With very little Emily is Away accomplishes so much. I don't think I have ever felt that my decisions mattered as much as they did here. Throughout the half hour of gameplay, the connection you make with Emily is really rather something powerful, and it's even more impressive when Emily is presented to us as just text on a screen. It's quite possibly the most realistic game I have ever played, the relationships are stunningly realised, the character development is some of the best I have ever seen and when you ♥♥♥♥ you, you really feel like you have ♥♥♥♥ed up.   I cannot reccomend this game enough. Yes it's short but the choose your own adventure style narrative makes it endlessly replayable and is easily one of the very best games of the year.

At first this game appeared to have promise based on the premise as well as the style of it. I was hoping at the very to experience some sense of nostalgia from the days of talking to my friends in school via aol instant messenger and how even those interactions, though just typing, could lead to some very meaningful, dramatic, and important conversations in hindsight. After playing this game however it was just bland and failed to invoke the slightest bit of feeling or even plain fun. It lacks depth to the writing and fails to build any attachement to the character you are speaking with and also harshly limits the actual choices available to you in a game that has very little gameplay outside of a short simulated conversation. Yes the game was free but it took something more valuable from me and everyone who played it, time. Avoid if you believe playing a video game should involve any sort of actual stimulation ourside basic motor reflexes and mental cognition.

Emily Is Away is a fantastic game. Not perfect, but fantastic. Without ever knowing what the characters looked like, and only reading the messages they sent between eachother was more than enough to learn everything about them. Though I do feel the game does need a few branching paths given the choices in what we say, I will say the ending is far more heartwrenching than anything I've seen recently. The games strips away choice because you don't get a choice. She's happy with someone else and there is nothing you can do about it. All you can do is sit there and watch yourself say something you don't wanna say while you're crying out on the inside wanting to tell her how you fell. I had a feeling of helplesness when I heard she had gotten back together with Brad, and I had it all the way through the final chapter. I would love to see this become a bigger game, maybe we could start from a few years earlier or go into the life of being an adult. All of it is amazing and I loved every second of the game.

I my where do I begin, well I guess the good things first.  The writing is not that bad, adn the ambient is nice enough to loose yourself in it. Thats about it. Now let's talk gameplay. In this game? please don't come here wih your expectation that games should challenge something about you.  You just read something, choose a response, and you read the response. Is a novel with nothing to say, you are better of with a nice book.  It's a way of telling a story designed to resonate just with certain age demographic. If you didn't lived it, you'll get nothing from it. And gets tired almost instantly.  The story, is your basic teenage drama. and I REALLY mean basic. No challenge, no flavor, its just a vanilla tasting heartbreak made to resonate with as much people as possible. If you like soap operas, this is for you, and only for you.  SPOILERS from here on Everything you do is pointless and you'll end up hating your main character at the end no matter what. The main problem I see is the lack of multiple endings, a game like this really needs them. The control the player has is meningless. This portrays his as whiny and annoying, unable to move on or fight. The story just goes by without him learning, growing, or actually interacting. He is the toy of everyone but the player, and has no control over himself.  This lack of development makes him one of the most boring characters I've ever encountered. But maybe I'm just a heartless monster. Oh, and Emmily, I really couldn't care less about her.   conclusion: Has a lot of work in it, I can't deny that, but it's wasted and missplaced. 4/10

If you grew up during the age of instant messengers or if you simply like to enjoy short stories, this game is worth one play-through. It's a depressing look into the friendship of two high school students who go their separate ways after graduation and will tug at a few heart strings before it's over.  That said, the game has almost zero replayability. There is only one ending, meaning the choices you have for every response to Emily are an illusion. Emily also 'remembers' what you said, but this doesn't affect the ending and only changes the dialogue a little bit.  I'm also not sure what the purpose of choosing your avatar is, because it only seems to be mentioned once in the entire game.  If this game had multiple endings I would give it a much stronger recommendation.

At first glance, this game looks like an extremely fun narrative driven game, based around the nostalgia of a time past. However, if you relate to the game as strongly as I did, you'll soon become overwhelmed by the feeling that it's no longer just a game but a retelling of scenarios that have happened time and time again, with the same results over and over. It may only be an hour long, but it was the most heart wrenching hour of my entire gaming career, more traumatizing than any decision in any game I've ever played. If you've been feeling like you need to cry about someone you've lost to the hustle and bustle of adult life, play this game. If you don't feel like crying, don't play this game. Plain and simple.

Want to relive the glory days of your baby internet self? Then get this game. It's free and simplistic, but very well done. It captivates you, compelling you to see how, in ten minutes, it plays out with your high school best friend, Emily. I really, really loved the Windows XP format... it had the familiar sights and sounds of IM (man, I   need   Emily's MUSE icon -- that was pretty sick). I replayed it a few times immediately after the first ending, only to find that it was the same ending each time? Perhaps it is too linear, but it did not detract from the good experience of the first playthrough. I would really love to see more, like extra chapters or a sequel or the ability to talk with some of the other characters.  Definitely recommend it, though.

This game gave me an existentalist crisis. I'm a sentimental person who has online friends that instant messaging has been my only form of contacting people. The AIM inpersonation, with the whole persona of being 'away,' makes me relive seemingly the biggest metaphorical roadblock I dealt with, having friends who I had never met, and never will meet, being 'away,' just reaches and scratches at that inaccessability, coupled with the few times that the parties involved are able to converse, a whole ocean growing between them with each passing year.  Even the Death Cab for Cutie lyrics in emily's profile, and for that matter, the song lyrics in everyone's profiles was not only an attribute to that angsty, emo, mid 2000s era, but served as a time capsule.   This game has left me heartbroken. I miss friends that I have yet to speak to for the very last time. Goodbye Goodbye Goodbye.

Good God... This game... I played this game around 1 hour. YES ONLY 1 HOUR! But experience is better then other adventure games i ever played. In the end i was sad... Really sad. In our lives, everyone break up with friend... And that whats why this game is that briliant. It's just like... It's you own story. Yes, i know this game is not AAA but all that glitters is not gold, you know. I gave this game 9/10 just because I felt so insecure from all of that what happen in the game, It was like... Someone whatching me all the time.

Even though the game tries to give you a sense of freedom in which replies you choose, you don't have any.  There are no multiple endings and to be honest there doesn't need to be any, don't replay!. It's predetermined: you have no chance with Emily, no chance with Emma and your life sucks d#ck. If you have no self esteem DON'T play this game or you'll suffer extraordinary pain that will cripple your heart far all eternity. But i need to aplaud Kyle Seeley for making such a nostalgic, painfull and almost cringeworthy experience ( in a good way ) to us all who suffered trough something simmilar.   The perfect 'friendzoned' experience.  8,6/10 would never play again.

An interactive game that lacks interactivity. Choices don’t seem to have much impact on what happens in the game. I started to lose it towards the end when the choices I chose to type were typed out, deleted, and then something was typed in its place that was completely different.  The game requires you to bash some buttons to mimic your character typing a message to Emily. After about five seconds this becomes incredibly tedious.  Finally the character you play as is pathetic. By the end of the game I was salty as hell with Emily but the only options for conversation I was given were things like “how do you feel?” and “are we still friends?”. I would have liked to see some more variety for potential messages, including some that would have made the character seem like less of a dweeb.  0/10 would not try to bang Emily again

My grandfather smoked his whole life. I was 10 years old when my mother said to him. 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop imiddiately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years layer he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Dont ever smoke. Please dont put your family through what your Grandfather put us through.' I agreed. At 21, I have never touched a cigareete. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for not having done it, because this game game me cancer anyway.

Amazing game. Of course, there's not a ton of replay value. It's the kind of thing you spend 30 minutes playing through and then forget about, so I think it would be great if there were some alternate endings. WARNING! THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS!  Emily is Gone is a mix for me. I think any free game deserves a chance, mostly just because i'm not paying money for them. I think the main problem with this game is that your choices hardly change the story, all they do is change the Dialog slightly. It's a shame really, there's just one ending and it is very cliché. It would have been nice if there were around 3 endings for the game. One of the more poinless things I liked about the game were the profile pictures you could unlock with cheat codes. Basically, you would make your in-game name something specific and you would unlock a picture. Most of the profile pictures are based on popular games EG. Fallout, Borderlands, Zelda. If you use one of them on the first level, Emily will comment on the picture and will normally make a reference to the game. Overall, Emily is Gone is a decent game to try for an hour or so, though because of just having one ending it has hardly any replay value. If this was a paid game, I definitely wouldn't be so forgiving.

This 'game' is an interesting concept with lots of nostalgia wrapped within it. It's not really that much of a game. It's more of a short interactive experience. The premise is that you are a person using AOL Instant Messenger who has a friend named Emily that you talk to throughout the game. The game spans the years 2002-2006 as the characters go through the senior year of highschool all the way to the senior year of college. You get to choose a screen name and a buddy icon for your character and there are some nice little nostalgic references with the buddy icons and the profiles of your friends having cringey song lyrics and stuff in them. To be honest though, the game itself is really something you would play once and never touch again. There are no alternate endings or interesting branching paths from your dialogue choices. No matter what you choose the game always ends the same. This is a good thing because it really helps with the message of the game, but unfortunately it also kills any replayability. There can also be also a disconnect between the player and your character. Some of the dialogue choices I found were not something I would say. I understand the message of the game being that people grow apart and relationships change over time, but I guess I'm just not into the whole young drama thing as entertainment. But hey, it's free. I would recommend giving it a try. You might find something worthwhile and relatable about it since the premise can get pretty close to home with people that have been in similar relationships.

After playing and completing this game a few times and making a bunch of different choices, I have found that this game has ultimately been an extremely linear experience. No matter if the player friendzones Emily, be mean to Emily, or even be extremely friendly to Emily, each choice will lead to the same result which revolves around Emily distancing herself from the player. Now, I understand that there is a life lesson behind this game's story, but I still felt extremely unsatisfied with the ending, Regardless, the game within itself is good in terms of its aesthetic appeal. If you are someone who has used an old computer from the early years of the 2000s, then you will be filled with nostalgia. The sound effects, interface, and even the subtle terminal noises will fill one with a sense of nostalgia and longing. The game was successful in capturing the true essence of life in the 'Stone Age' of computers, and for that, I was content with the game itself. Regardless, I was expecting more from this game, but I still found that game to be okay.

'Emily is such a sweet character.' No.  'Your choices actually matter.' nO.  'Just say you love her!' NO.  Tl;dr: Interesting concept. Short, unsatisfying, but realistic characters and story. Not bad for a free game, but not recommending because your choices don't matter and you get blamed for it all.  Emily is an incredibly manipulative and emotionally abusive girl. Your choices only affect the ways in which your character is strung along and blamed for Emily's choices. Go to that party she wants you to come to? Sorry, you didn't come onto her enough. Want to be there for her in her time of need? Too bad, she now blames you for your (supposed) advances. Want to try to talk things over? Emily is away.  If you're going for an emotional abuse simulator, this is exactly what you want. Otherwise, it's a somewhat tragic story of a girl who needs help and goes looking for love from people who treat her badly, and her once-close friend who never quite got over her manipulation.

I always said there is no such thing as a friendzone. Whenever a guy has said that it is when he becomes friends with a girl, tries to lure them in by being nice to her and acting like her friend, then tries to ask her out, and learns she is not attracted to him. That's not friendzone that's rejection; they have no physical attraction to you, so they do not see you as a potential mate in a sexual, romantic, or any other kind of way. However, This game made me see first hand that the friendzone is not only very real, but is a dangerous place. It is like being in purgatory whilst alive. I would never intentionally do that to someone, and Emily deserves to be with a guy to who treats her like crap since she treats the only guy who is nice to her like crap. Thank you, for making me finally believe in the friendzone.

Do you like free games that are easy to 100%? Are you afraid of forgetting how Windows XP and AIM looked/sounded? Would you like to be temporarily transported back to ~2002-2006 on a nostalgia-fueled roller coaster ride? If you answered yes to any of those questions, you're in the right place.  This game tells the story of your friendship with Emily, which you explore through yearly chat sessions over AIM. The story itself is pretty linear; choosing different dialogue options pretty much just changes some flavor text. But at the end, it left me silent and wondering how everything went so wrong with my real-life friendships. What happened to those friends I used to be so close to? Why did they seem to just disappear before my very eyes? Was there anything I could have done to stop it? Or were these relationships doomed to fail from the very start?  There is also references and memes, and I'm always a sucker for those. On top of that, something that so closely resembles Windows XP looks really funny (in a good way) on a Mac.  The game is free, and one playthrough takes maybe thirty minutes, so it's definitely worth a shot.
