TIME TO COMPLETE: 0.8 hours TIME TO COMPLETE ACHIEVEMENTS: 1 hour  Emily is Away acts as one of those free, short games which you always tell yourself you'd finish but fail to do so. At its core it's mostly a multi-choice game.  Here comes the days when there was no Facebook nor Skype but MSN with Yahoo!Messenger ruled the world. Players get to talk with a girl called Emily (just as the name suggests) and that's the main premise, but there are quite a lot of possibilities which you can brach into though it doesn't feel as many as they could be. The game unfortunately ends with you running out of questions to ask and all options being flooded with 'Goodbye'. That is unless you give up earlier than you should but that's about it.  There's also a little customization going on: you can change the avatar, text color and background. If you give yourself the right username you will be greeted with twice as many avatars, most of them easter eggs which branch into funny references at the start of each conversation but ultimately go back to normal. This is another reason why the game lacks replayability but I think it's also because there are so many choices to do it'd be painful to have multiple storylines for them all.  Among the surprises you get to experience is having your Steam friends included within the in-game friend list which is also quite funny since every profile has their own (I think random?) generated personal text. Currently I am unaware if it can use all of your friends or only those that are online during your play but nevertheless it's a lot of fun. Will generate a lot of reactions.  Overall it's a fun game which I advise everyone to try. It takes about one hour at most to finish and that is without unlocking every achievement. I also need to mention the fact that the game makes you press your keyboard whenever a choice is made as if you were typing, further adding to immersion.

This game was definitely a fun story(ies?). I enjoyed resetting and choosing different options to see how the story will change and how the choices would lead into different events. If one is into narratives and choose-your-own-adventure kind of interactive games, then this is a nice, short little adventure into the lives of two friends over the course of five years.  What I especially loved were the little buddy info pages of the various characters mentioned in the game, where you can learn little tidbits like Travis's loss, Mike's growing formality and Emma's interest in the same music as Emily.  Now, spoilers for those who haven't played the game yet and are reading reviews ahead of time, while I liked how Emily and the Player drift apart in the end no matter what you choose from a creative standpoint because of how painfully realistic it is, my emotions beg to differ. Gah, how I longed to piece back the relationship.  What's fascinating is that Emily did feel like an actual person in her dialogue and my friend, even though I didn't really know much about her, save some of her favorite music, her relationships, and that's she's an overall friendly person who holds a high opinion of the player. It actually reminded me of a friend I actually have in real life where the situation was actually quite similar, and along with the style of the game I was definitely sent down a nostalgia trip.   I do wish that the characters were a little more fleshed out, that I could also chat with Emma and Travis and Julie, that the little 'Emily will remember that' or 'You chose to go to art school' made more of a difference down the road like some of the other notes that appeared, but I understand that it's a free game. I guess you could say I enjoyed it so much I wanted more of it.  I definitely connected emotionally with this game and enjoyed exploring all the different ways the story could have gone as well as putting on different personas the options suggested. I'm certainly glad I came across it.

You got friendzoned and there's no hope of gaining a romance relationship with her? Your relationship with her is on a brink of destruction? Tell her to play this game. I don't know how. Just. Let. Her. Play. This. Game.

An inescapable story of inevitable self-friendzoning. If you try to advance the story in a different direction by choosing a dialogue option to confess your feelings or ask for an honest discussion, your in-game character chickens out, deletes the dialogue and goes for something completely mundane instead.   Even if you try to choose Emma over Emily,   and discourage Emily from visiting you so you don't have to ditch your preplanned weekend with Emma, it's revealed in the end that     Emma got tired of waiting for you to make a move and lost interest in you.    Strange how many reviews are 'so sad, so friendzoned' or even getting annoyed with Emily, when the behaviour of the player character is so weak and indecisive.  It's a fun little game with a certain amount of replay value to explore the dialogue trees and unlock some fun secrets, but the main elements of the story are set in stone. Great for what it is - a cute little (FREE!) indie game that rides on nostalgia and some interesting observations on human nature.

Really not a lot more to this game other than the fact it's free and goes for half an hour. I can see how the aesthetics and 'gameplay' would be nostalic for a lot of people but the 'typing' system is clunky and doesn't feel fluent (as in, it gets in the way) and there's only really one plot you have no control over, resulting in a game that doesn't feel like it lives up to what it should be.   This game is listed as a 'Virtual Novel', 'Dating Sim' and 'Choose your own adventure', but I'd really just list it as a 'Instant Messaging Tour' because it's actually none of those first 3.   I was open to this game at the start, but with an opening premise as unique and interesting as EiA, the end result is anti-climactic and comes across very lack-luster. This game is the epitome of the term 'Wasted Potential.' No idea how this game has such high praise. It's as if people are reacting to what it COULD have been, as opposed to what it is.

This was one awesome game, I gotta say. As a kid who never really had an old computer with the more older versions of windows, it was a nice memory revisited from the little times I did see it. Although it's a cool theme, that's not what my favorite thing about this game was. My favorite thing was the amount of reality soaked in it. It oozes real life sceneorios with themes like growing up, going to college, having a High School friend you'll not sure what was going on in between you guys, trying to keep relashonships going, and just the fact it can really show off some elements off your personality, as well as some very hard choices to make, are you going to try to keep a past love flame going, or are you just going to try and forget it ever happened? The replay abilty of this game is also very fantastic with the amount of choices you could of made and you might try to get a better ending, when there might not even be a better ending. And that is for you to find out. It's FREE and great, I totally reccomend giving it a go!

This game raises a lot of intresting questions on the effects of social media on relationships. How focusing on what could have been rather than what could ruin the future. I like the game overall, there is one huge flaw I found with the tennure of the game which I will list below, considering it has some spoilers I suggest playing through the game before reading, it will only take an hour, and at the very least it's an intresting perspective, even though I feel if this game was given a budget a lot more could be done to explore it's concepts and themes.    Suggestion to make it better (slight spoilers): I felt the ending is right, it has a great punch and really makes you think however, I think you should be able to focus on you're relationship with Emma. I feel like like if you go through with ditching Emma you have chosen a future, rather than finding out what could have been with a nice fresh stable relationship. I feel the message is hurt by no matter what you do the game essentailly ending in a fail state. If you could chose Emma, sure you may have a fail state with Emily, but a prospurous relationship with Emma. If you can't end up with Emma, why would you chose to spend time with her over Emily. By allowing an ending a choice where you chose Emma, you admit that you may have at one point loved Emily, however, so much time has past and you have a good thing going, you know that spending time with this old flame could jepordize your relationship with Emma, so you have an actaul choice, do you sacrafice the thing you have now for a chance at a missed opurtunity in the past that is a wild card, or do you stay with the sure thing the girl that is in your life now and wants you now.

This game is really cool. It manages to really simulate what it's really like have a friendly texting relationship with a girl that you kinda like, but she doesn't know that. I found that I really could express my real self through the three dialogue choices. It's not very long, but I could easily really get into the story, it was strangely relatable. The immersion is excellent, the sound effects were the icing on the cake in my perspective. Overall it is great game, and the fact that it was made for an older generation than mine, and yet the fact that it is still understandable, and that there weren't a ton of references thrown at you, although there still were all throughout for nostalgia's sake, I could still really enjoy the game. This really was an experience, I'll probably actually do multiple playthroughs of the game just to experience all of what the game still has in stock for me. 10/10 A lot of hard work and effort was put forth in making this game, thanks for the trip, can't wait to see what else is to come from this dev. :p

Nice aesthetic. Cool pop culture references, including some that will hit you right in the nostalgia gut (dem MSN Messenger icons). The story is simple and straightforward, and one that I feel many of us may relate when it comes to situations in which we ended up just drifting apart from old friends despite still desperately trying to cling to them.  The downside is that Emily herself seems quite... 'confused', or even inconsistent at times (in one year she acts like she's bitter about this thing, the next year she seems to not want/not care about it anymore, then she's sad about it), and it's a little disappointing how your choices dont have that big an impact on the outcome and you just get that bittersweet end, no matter what.  It would be interesting to see an extended version (maybe a paid version) with more endings, more choices, and in which the side-characters play a bigger part (maybe you can chat with Travis, Mike, Emma et al.)  Still pretty entertaining though. It's also quick and hey, it's free, so why not try it out?

I decided to pick this game up on a lark, but didn't know that I would be playing a game that really tugged at my heart and brought me back to a time when emotions were at the surface and reminded me how easy it is for relationships to build or fall apart.  As short as my play was and how much I would love to go back and try out new angles and dialogue, I can't bring myself to restart the game - partly because it's late, but also because I'm trying to process the emotional roller coaster I just went on. The minimalist style and storytelling on display here was really top-knotch and I think I've found a game that is in my Top 10 personal favorites. Personally, it's up there for me with The Beginner's Guide for having a sharp, twisting gut reaction that is going to leave me awake tonight unless I find something to disract me.

What an odd game. Emily is Away is a semi-choice based game, not designed for those that turn their noses to walking-simulators and visual novel experiences.  While the game is extremely short (could be beaten in half an hour, maybe 20 minutes tops), it manages to squeeze an awful lot of feels out in the short time span.  The game is also free-to-play so you really don't have much of anything to lose in playing it.  The game takes you back to the days of instant messaging, akin to Yahoo Messenger and the like. Where you message a girl named Emily for a bit, once a year for 5 years. You talk about your lives and connect and learn each others stories and form a friendship.  There is no way to substantially alter the outcome of the story, almost all endings are the same, regardless of user input during the course of the game.  Yes, I think it would make more sense to add some other endings to the game where the player choices make more meaningful impacts on the outcome, but at the same time, this isn't something I expect out of a free-to-play game. They game is definitely worth the one time experience.

So, this game was an emotional ride from start to finish. I really like how the conversation between you and emily starts off as a normal conversation between friends and it the develops and there is that small window of oppurtinity that you will begin to date. Unfortunately that didnt happen and I just sat there as I had to choose an option while my character typed it out, deleted it and wrote something else, which was very sad to witness.  I think the inclusion of choosing the text option and then with eack key press it types the message was a really good design choice as it gave that added sense of that you were in control, but the game still had control over where the story was going to after you chose the initial choices.   The only downside I can really give this game is the UI. For whatever reason, the UI is a bit bugged and you need to position the mouse slighty to the right of the intended button. Although it is a minor thing, it still is a downside.  All in all, I think this was a really good game for being free. I hope you make more awesome games like this in the future.

not a very long game in general, but it gives you the option to have different scenario's play out by the text options you choose. You play as a guy (You get to choose the name.) And you basically talk with a friend known as Emily, you two have gone through highschool together, and now you both of you are going to different colleges. However before parting ways there is a party, emily is curious if you will attend it. Will you go, or will you stay home and just watch paint dry? Choice is yours, and from their on out you and emily have a on and off conversation on aim. Interesting enough this game does really well in playing out a scenario that I'm sure everyone has gone through having a thing for someone, but just weren't able to tell them how you felt. Overall I would recommend playing the game once or twice just to try it out.

This game is a narrative about a falling out between two people. Human relationships are fickle, and this game really describes how easily relationships are ended and how easily new ones are made. The narrative was simple, yet also quite diverse in the branches. However, no matter what path you take, it seems that nothing really changes. You always end up taking back the words you should have said-- just like in real life. It's really sad when you think about it, but life works that way. I really liked how the narrative functioned in the game, and, for a free game, there's really nothing I would rather change.  8/10

I reviewed this a while back with very little words. Previously, I had written a review with the intent of it being a joke, however playing the game again, I've decided to write an actual review. This will contain spoilers. Please be aware.   Emily is Away begins with you, the protagonist, having a dearly close comrade called Emily, as expected from the game title itself. No matter what you do, it will end with you bidding farewell to Emily. Throughout the game, the protagonist will try to express his/her love for Emily, but fails to do so as he/she is afraid (what I would assume. I'm not entirely positive).   From my own perspective, once I had finished the game, I teared up a bit. I played this back in 2015 with a friend whilst we were joking about indie games and more or less insulting it. Just to tell you the end of this little throwback, I was crying while in a Skype call with said friend.  All in all, this game just hit home, and it's simply amazing.

It's a short game that really captures the nostalgia of what it was like to be a college kid during the 2000s period on AOL's instant messenger. The conversations in this game mimicked my own relationships back then. Some of the conversations were dead on, even the jokes, which made me feel like people back then weren't very clever.   Give it a shot and play the game. It's only 20 minutes long.
